have to be careful when it's like to be a biblical believer on all fronts of life. Like,
this is exactly what you have to do when it comes to lesser things like diet and, you know,

It's never enough. There's always something else. So yeah, it's not teaching those around you or

Yep. When it's a conversation, you're able to have together with family and friends and,

I think we do have time. I think it's worth it. Yeah. What was the, I think,

Yeah. I thought it was such a, she described her own struggle with this so articulately. I thought

Or for example, he's all powerful and all knowing, and yet things are happening in the world because

Yep. So this is a thought, Chris. Well, it is an old question. And these three things,

maybe I can find it. But anyway, there's a famous way of just like one phrase saying it that if we
can find it, that'll be great. But the idea being, as she pointed out, you know, that, you know,
in a God that has any two of these traits is plausible, I guess, but you add in the third one.

problem comes down to all knowing. I think all knowing is what throws people off, is that they

doesn't mean you wouldn't want suffering. There are lots of good things that come from suffering.
In fact, there's a lot of good things in the human experience now that only suffering can lead to.
And someone could say, well, God could create a universe where good things could come without
suffering. Maybe if that's logically plausible. But that's, that's God's prerogative. But that's
God's prerogative. In this conversation. Yeah. Right. And so, and so if you say if, if God is,
is all good, that he wouldn't make the people wouldn't suffer. And that's just, I think they
that statement is a statement I would disagree with. And it connects to if God is all knowing,
then he would know how to keep people from suffering. And if he was all powerful,
then he could keep them from suffering. And so why is there suffering? And so I think
that's the fundamental question. And I think, I think what we're looking at with this is
what we talked about a long time ago with David Smalley and others that we've talked to.
And it comes down to the fact that if God is all knowing, he would know exactly what amount of

morally sound. And we have a thousand different analogies that we can all do. Under the all good

if he could have spoken, he would have said, you know, Mommy, why are you allowing me to suffer

even though that does not perfectly apply, obviously, the carrots, the understanding that

God doesn't cause things like child abuse. And, you know, right? Yeah, you wouldn't have to be that
he caused it. It could be that he just allowed it. And why wouldn't God stop it? Well, God knows
what happens if the person is abused. And God knows what happens if they aren't abused. And
He knows how that cascades out into all of creation. And so apparently has decided that
there is a worthwhile, there's a morally worthwhile benefit to that type of suffering.
And again, that sounds horrible. And I can't fathom it. And I don't understand it. And like,
I don't have to understand it. I don't understand why doctors have to do vaccines the way they do

Go ahead. Well, so but are you saying you think that everything God allows

morally sufficient reason for allowing suffering. If he ever doesn't have a morally sufficient reason,
then he should cause it. He should stop it. Right. But I'm saying we can't necessarily say

precise way of saying is, is that God has a God apparently has a morally sufficient reason
for allowing whatever suffering He allows. I do think you have to have that. Go ahead.
Well, I was just saying we were just thinking back to a response from a listener that we had

really traumatic, hard things can seem insensitive, right? Just because it's like, how could you
compare the abuse that I experienced as a child to going to the dentist or, you know, like,
even though it's not, it can seem like it's insensitive or over simplifying someone's pain

I'm sorry. We're a little, we've got a little delay here. Apparently.
I think it's, I know, I'm sorry. I thought you were, I wasn't trying to interrupt. Um,
but at the same time, I think when you're in the midst of such a heart wrenching pain,

Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. It's not. And, and that's one of the difficulties is, and that's what,

I thought maybe the most insightful thing that I love that she said was when she said she

her friend's mental illness or for his suicide. And for that,
his searching. Yeah. And I thought that was really potent because, uh, again, that goes back to what
we've talked about before. Like I, yeah, I would agree. I don't think I would want to follow a God

Right. So what do you do with, you know, that when it comes to, it doesn't seem that God is,

I don't know where to begin with that. Like what was going on? It's a great question. Yeah. It is.
It's a great question. And I hate, you know, obviously, I mean, we, we would all hate for
her that in the end he ended up taking his own life. And then how I just, you hate to say, well,
you know, there's this such a strong, you know, while there's life, there's hope,
feeling about the world. And you just, you just, it's so sad and heartbreaking. And it's not,
there's not an easy answer to these things and there's not going to be. Yeah. Um, and that's,

I still feel like theism has the best answer. Um, and that's that there, there is a God who can

nonetheless. Yeah. Yeah. I so appreciate her bringing these things though. I mean, what,
what a great, um, what a great conversation and to give us the opportunity to wrestle with them
as well. So yeah. Yeah. And not just on an intellectual level. I think it's so important

Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoyed what you

If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
